author: @killthedark7283
text: For the people who are watching this, I hope my comment helps you out.  Standard Deviation: You are sampling one sample from the population to see how the value spread from the mean Standard Error: You are sampling more than one sample from the population to see how the mean spread from each sample.

author: @sanchitakanta1018
text: Standard error for the sample mean= s/ sqrt(n) Where,  s is the standard deviation of sample and n is the size of the sample.  Whereas the formula for  standard deviation of the sampling distribution for mean= Sp/ sqrt(n) Where Sp is standard deviation of the population mean.  In one formula we are using parameter and in the other one we are the standard deviation of the sample.Why is it so?  Can someone please explain.   As far as I understood standard error is the standard deviation of the mean. Then, why is this difference in the formula?

Standard error quantifies the deviation of multiple means from the true mean, from multiple data sets.
